pr_title: Drop http2 request in two cases

timeline.bodyText: Is there a reason for dropping the connection at this point as opposed to just waiting until the router tells the NetworkClient to drop the request after routerRequestTimeoutMs? At this point, the request has already been flushed successfully so the request memory would have already been freed.
timeline.author: cgtz

replies.bodyText: I agree with you . Changed http2DropRequestOnWriteAndFlushTimeout to false by default.
replies.author: zzmao

replies.bodyText:
Want to discuss with your guys @justinlin-linkedin @cgtz :
If a request is flushed successfully(here), its refCnt is decreased, but there is a reference chain that AttributeKey<RequestInfo> -> PutRequest -> Bytebuf, so even refCnt is 0, data is still in memory and can't be recycled. Is this something we can improve?
replies.author: zzmao

replies.bodyText: I am not worried about this. Comparing to the small object ByteBuf, the byte content held by ByteBuf is way larger. As long as the byte content can be reclaimed by the memory pool, we can ignore the small ByteBuf object.
replies.author: justinlin-linkedin

replies.bodyText:
Not fully understand your comment.
If it's PutRquest and it holds big chunk of data, we should break the link between PutRequst -> ByteBuf, for GC to recycle, right?
replies.author: zzmao

replies.bodyText: Yes and no. When using Unpooled bytebuf, big chunk of data will rely on gc to release the memory. When using Pooled ByteBuf, big chunk of data will rely on calling release method to return the chunk back to the pool. GC doesn't reclaim the data chunk, only the small heap memory of ByteBuf fields.
replies.author: justinlin-linkedin

timeline.bodyText: is there a possibility that redyResponseInfos contain responses for the dropped request? if so, do we care?
timeline.author: justinlin-linkedin

replies.bodyText: It should include responses from dropped request. That's how router knows it was drooped.
replies.author: zzmao

timeline.bodyText: Also, should probably remove the correlationIds for these responses from the inflight map.
timeline.author: justinlin-linkedin

replies.bodyText:
Good catch. Re-organized the map logic:
add: when a stream is acquired
remove: after http2ClientResponseHandler.getResponseInfoQueue().poll()
replies.author: zzmao

replies.bodyText: Does this mean that a request cannot be dropped if stream acquisition takes a long time? I guess that is okay since that may be a rare occurrence and would require some complicated logic in the acquire listener to determine if the request can be sent or not.
replies.author: cgtz

replies.bodyText:
You are right, if a stream is not acquired, it's won't be in inflight map, so it can't be dropped. It's rare, we don't expect stream acquisition takes a long time.
And since the inflight map's value is streamChannel(to close it in case of drop request), we can't add <correlationId, streamChannel> to inflight map before stream acquisition done.
An extra time check can be made right after stream acquired if it's really need.
replies.author: zzmao

timeline.bodyText: what is this? This handler is not used anywhere, and it seems like we are trying to print out some info when it's a stream exception, which makes this a stream handler, doesn't stream handler belong to Http2NetworkClient.StreamChannelInitializer?
timeline.author: justinlin-linkedin

replies.bodyText:
If a request is drop, its streamChannel will be closed, but if a response is already inflight, and then arrives client.
Http2MultiplexHandler will report unknown stream id error and print a long stack.
The handler here is to avoid such useless stack in our log.
replies.author: zzmao

replies.bodyText: Are we sure that all resources on child channels will be released if the exception is caught and swallowed here?
replies.author: cgtz

timeline.author: justinlin-linkedin

timeline.bodyText: is this added to the pipeline anywhere?
timeline.author: cgtz

replies.bodyText: yes, added to connection pipeline. Stream pipeline is not impacted.
replies.author: zzmao

timeline.bodyText: "which from..." -> "for a request which was already dropped"
timeline.author: cgtz

timeline.bodyText: nit: remove whitespace at the end of these log messages
timeline.author: cgtz
cgtz

timeline.bodyText: Why doesn't the ref count get decremented in other exception cases? Are we assuming that other exception cases come from ChannelHandlers written by Ambry that don't decrement the ref count?
timeline.author: cgtz

replies.bodyText: It's because I am not clear when exactly refCnt is decreased. Let me do more reading.
replies.author: zzmao
zzmao
